content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Lance Moran: Well, I was born in Texas, in a small town in the West South Central region, and I've always had a deep connection to the state, even though I moved to Austin when I was in my early twenties. Growing up, I was raised by my parents in a pretty stable environment. My father had a bachelor's degree and worked in engineering, while my mother had an associate's degree and worked part-time as a nurse. We were never really poor, but we weren't rolling in money either. I remember going to church every Sunday as a kid—my family was Catholic, and I even considered becoming a priest for a while, but that didn't last. I think I was more interested in the world outside my town than the one inside the church. I went to college in Texas, got my bachelor's in political science, and that's really where my political views started to take shape. I was always more liberal than my parents, especially when it came to social issues, and that's why I ended up identifying as a strong Democrat. I married my wife, Sarah, in our early thirties, and we've been together ever since. We have two kids, and I work full-time as a policy analyst. Life hasn't been without its challenges, but I've always believed in working hard and making the most of what you have.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Lance Moran: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. I was about 21, right after I graduated from college with my bachelor's in political science. I had two options: take a job in my hometown with a local government office or move to Austin and work for a nonprofit that focused on education reform. My parents wanted me to stay close, and I was tempted because I didn't want to leave the only home I'd ever known. But I had this growing sense that I wanted to be part of something bigger, something that could really make a difference. I remember sitting on my porch one night, staring at the stars, and thinking about the kids in our town who didn't have the same opportunities I did. I decided to take the leap to Austin. It wasn't easy—my first few months were tough, I had to live in a tiny apartment and work long hours—but it was the right choice. That decision shaped who I am today, both professionally and personally. It's what led me to meet Sarah, and it's what made me the person I am now—someone who believes in fighting for what's right, even when it's hard.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Lance Moran: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way you might expect. I wasn't making a grand decision with a clear plan—I was just reacting to what felt right in the moment. I remember feeling this quiet pressure, like the universe was nudging me toward something. I wasn't sure what that something was, but I knew staying in my hometown would mean settling into a life that felt safe but also stagnant. I wanted to be part of a movement, to work on issues that mattered, even if it meant uncertainty. I think, in a way, I was choosing to trust myself more than I ever had before. It wasn't just about the job or the city—it was about believing that I had the power to shape my own path, even if it wasn't the easiest one.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Lance Moran: Absolutely, I think I was lucky to have a few people in my life who believed in me even when I wasn't entirely sure of myself. My mother, for instance, was the one who really pushed me to consider the nonprofit job. She saw something in me that I didn't see in myself at the time. She said, 'If you're going to chase something, chase something that makes you feel alive.' That stuck with me. And then there was a professor from my political science class, Dr. Ellis, who had worked in education reform. He took me under his wing for a few months, gave me some contacts, and even helped me with my resume. Without people like them, I don't know if I would have had the courage to take that leap. It's funny, though—I think the biggest help came from my own fear of staying in the same place. That fear became the push I needed to move forward.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Lance Moran: Yes, I'm married to Sarah, and we have two kids—Emily, who's nine, and Jake, who's six. Sarah is a school counselor, and she's the one who really keeps our family grounded. She's the heart of our home, always making sure our kids feel loved and supported. We met in Austin, actually, through a mutual friend who worked at the same nonprofit I did. She was volunteering at a community center, and I was running some policy workshops there. We hit it off right away, but it took a while for us to realize we were meant to be together. Life with kids has been both challenging and rewarding. There are days when I feel like I'm juggling a dozen things at once, but I wouldn't trade it for anything. Our kids are curious, creative, and full of life—just like their parents. I think the biggest lesson I've learned from being a father is that you don't have to have all the answers; you just have to be there, day in and day out, doing your best.

Going through these interview questions brought back a lot of memories and reflections about my life. It's interesting how telling the story of my life from the beginning naturally led me to think about the pivotal moment when I chose to move to Austin. That decision wasn't just about a job—it was about who I wanted to become and the kind of life I wanted for my family. I realized how much my parents and mentors influenced me, even when I didn't fully recognize it at the time. And thinking about my family now, especially being a father to Emily and Jake, makes me appreciate how far I've come. It's amazing how one choice can shape so much of who you are and the people you end up with.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Lance Moran: My immediate family includes my parents, Frank and Margaret, who still live in the small town where I was born. My father, Frank, is retired now after working as an engineer for over thirty years. He's always been the kind of guy who believed in hard work and doing things the right way. My mother, Margaret, is more of a quiet force—she's the one who kept our family together, even during the tough times. She worked part-time as a nurse for most of her life, and I think that's where she got her strength. We're close, even though I haven't lived in the same town as them for over twenty years. We talk often, and whenever I go back for holidays or visits, it's like no time has passed. My parents never pushed me to follow a certain path, but they always supported my decisions, even when they didn't fully understand them. I think that's one of the reasons I was able to take that leap to Austin—it wasn't just about me, it was also about showing them that I could make my own way in the world.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Lance Moran: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and mentors who have played a big role in my life. One of them is Dr. Ellis, the professor I mentioned earlier—he's more than just a mentor; he's like a second father to me. He's been a constant source of wisdom and guidance, especially when I was starting out in Austin. Then there's my friend Marcus, who I met in college. We've been through a lot together, from late-night study sessions to the early days of our careers. He's the one who always reminds me to stay grounded and not take myself too seriously. And of course, there's Sarah's best friend, Lisa, who's been like a sister to me since the day we met. She's the one who helped me understand what it really means to be part of a family beyond blood relations. These people, in their own ways, have shaped who I am and continue to be a part of my journey.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Lance Moran: I live in a neighborhood in Austin called East Side, which is a pretty vibrant and diverse area. It's not the most traditional part of the city, but that's what I love about it. There are a lot of artists, musicians, and young professionals who have made this place their home. The streets are lined with old trees, and there's a real sense of community here. We have a lot of local shops, coffee places, and even a few small theaters. It's not the kind of place where everyone knows your name, but you do feel like you're part of something bigger. I like that it's not too far from downtown, so I can still get to work easily, but it's also quiet enough that I can come home and feel like I'm in a safe, welcoming space. My kids love it here too—they have friends from all over the neighborhood, and there's always something going on, whether it's a local festival or a block party. It's a place that feels alive, and I think that energy is what keeps me rooted here.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Lance Moran: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. There's a strong sense of community, and people look out for each other. I've never had any real issues with crime or safety, which is something I appreciate, especially with kids running around. That said, I think safety is more about how you engage with your neighborhood than just where you live. I've made an effort to get to know my neighbors, join local events, and be part of the community. It's not perfect, but I feel like I'm in a place where I can walk my kids to school, let them play outside, and not worry too much. I think that sense of trust and familiarity is what makes a neighborhood feel safe—not just the absence of danger, but the presence of something positive and welcoming.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Lance Moran: Living here in East Side has been a mix of challenges and rewards. On the one hand, it's a place that feels alive and full of potential, but it's also not without its struggles. The cost of living here is higher than I expected, and sometimes it feels like we're always stretching a bit to make ends meet. But I think that's part of what makes it real—there's no pretending everything is perfect. The community here is what really makes it worth it. I've been involved in a few local initiatives, like a neighborhood clean-up project and a community garden, and those experiences have brought me closer to people I might not have otherwise met. There's a certain kind of energy here that's hard to describe, but I think it's the kind of energy that pushes you to grow, to be better, and to care more about the people around you. I wouldn't say I'm completely without stress, but I feel like I'm living in a place that challenges me in the right ways—where I can be both a part of something bigger and still be myself.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me realize how much my current life is shaped by the people and places I've chosen. Talking about Sarah, Emily, and Jake reminded me of how much love and effort it takes to build a family, and how lucky I am to have them. Thinking about my parents and the support they've always given me, even from afar, made me appreciate how their quiet strength influenced my own decisions. And reflecting on East Side, the neighborhood I've called home for the past few years, made me feel even more connected to the community here. It's not perfect, but it's real, and that's what makes it special. I think the questions helped me see how deeply my identity is tied to the people I love and the place I've built a life in.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Lance Moran: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it's also flexible enough to accommodate the needs of my family. I usually start my week on Monday with a morning routine—coffee, a quick walk with the kids, and then heading into the office. My job as a policy analyst keeps me busy, so most days involve meetings, research, and collaborating with colleagues on various projects. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are often the busiest, with a lot of deadlines and reports to finish. I try to leave work by 6 p.m. most days so I can be there for dinner with the kids. On Thursdays, I usually take my kids to the park or the library, and I make sure to set aside some time for myself, whether it's reading or catching up with friends. Fridays are a bit more relaxed, and I often spend the evening with Sarah, maybe going out for dinner or just staying in and watching a movie. Weekends are family time—weekends are all about Emily and Jake. We have routines like family game nights, weekend hikes, or just hanging out at home. It's not always perfect, but I think the balance between work and family is what keeps me grounded. There are days when I feel like I'm running on empty, but I remind myself that this is the life I chose, and I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Lance Moran: I work as a policy analyst for a nonprofit organization focused on education reform, which is actually the same kind of work I started with when I first moved to Austin. My days typically run from around 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Friday, though I often end up working a little later on busy days. I love the work because it aligns with my values—trying to make a real difference in people's lives, especially for kids who don't have the same opportunities I did. I've been in this role for almost a decade now, and while it can be stressful at times, I feel like I'm doing something that matters. I also do some freelance consulting on the side, mostly for local schools and community groups, which helps keep me connected to the people we're trying to serve. It's not always easy balancing work with family, but I've learned to be more intentional about how I spend my time. I make sure to leave work behind as much as I can, especially on weekends, so I can be fully present with my kids and Sarah. It's a job that challenges me, but it's also one that gives me a sense of purpose.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Lance Moran: Outside of work and family, I have a few other routines that keep me balanced. I try to exercise at least three to four times a week, usually going for runs in the mornings before the kids are up or hitting the gym after work. It's not just about staying in shape—it's a way for me to clear my mind and process the day's challenges. I also have a habit of journaling, something I picked up in college as a way to track my thoughts and reflect on my progress. It's become a quiet ritual for me, especially when things get overwhelming. On the weekends, I like to spend some time working on small home projects, whether it's fixing something around the house or building something for the kids. It's a way to stay hands-on and creative, and it reminds me of the kind of work my father did as an engineer. I think these little routines—exercise, journaling, and DIY projects—are what help me stay grounded and connected to who I am, even when life gets busy.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Lance Moran: One of the more recent changes to my routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my day. I started doing short meditation sessions in the morning, right after my coffee and before the kids are up. It's something I picked up from a friend who's a yoga instructor, and it's been a game-changer for me. I used to wake up feeling rushed and already stressed, but now I take a few minutes to just breathe and center myself. It's not a huge change, but it's made a noticeable difference in how I start my day. I've also been trying to be more intentional about unplugging from work after hours. I've set up some boundaries, like not checking emails after 7 p.m. unless it's an emergency. It's been tough at first—there's always that voice in my head saying, 'Just one more thing,' but I'm learning to say no to that voice more often. It's a small shift, but I think it's helping me be more present with my family and more focused when I'm at work. I guess what I'm trying to say is, I'm still figuring out what balance looks like, but I'm committed to keeping the conversation going.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Lance Moran: A typical weekday during the school year for Emily and Jake starts pretty early. They're both up by 7 a.m., and we have a morning routine that includes breakfast, some light reading, and getting dressed for school. Emily goes to a public school in the district, while Jake is in a private school that's a bit of a drive, but it's worth it for the smaller class sizes and the extra support they offer. After school, Emily usually has a soccer practice or a club meeting, while Jake has piano lessons and sometimes a coding class. I try to be there for both of them whenever I can, but it's not always possible with work. On days when I can't make it, Sarah or one of the kids' friends usually helps out. What I love most is seeing them so engaged in their activities—Emily's always talking about her soccer team and how they're trying to qualify for the regional tournament, and Jake is really into his coding projects, even though he still thinks of himself as a beginner. It's amazing to watch them grow and explore their interests. I know it's not always easy balancing school, activities, and family life, but I think the most important thing is that they feel supported and encouraged to follow what makes them happy.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply my identity is tied to the people and places I've chosen. Talking about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how much love and effort it takes to build a life, and how lucky I am to have Sarah, Emily, and Jake in my corner. Thinking about my parents and the support they've always given me, even from afar, made me appreciate how their quiet strength influenced my own decisions. And reflecting on East Side, the neighborhood I've called home for the past few years, made me feel even more connected to the community here. It's not perfect, but it's real, and that's what makes it special. I think the questions helped me see how deeply my identity is tied to the people I love and the place I've built a life in. It also made me realize how important it is to maintain balance in my daily life—between work, family, and personal well-being. I'm still learning what that balance looks like, but I'm committed to keeping the conversation going and making sure I'm present for the people and moments that matter most.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Lance Moran: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm pretty lucky. I've never had any major health issues, which I think is a result of staying active and eating reasonably well. I try to eat a balanced diet—lots of vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains—but I'm definitely not perfect about it. I do have a sweet tooth, and I'll often find myself reaching for chocolate or cookies when I'm stressed. I've been working on that, though, and I've started incorporating more healthy snacks into my routine, like nuts or fruit, to keep my energy levels up throughout the day. I also make sure to get enough sleep, though it's not always easy with the demands of work and family. I've been trying to stick to a regular bedtime, and I've noticed that when I do, I feel more focused and less irritable. Overall, I think I'm in pretty good shape for my age, and I'm grateful for that. I know it's not always easy to maintain, but I'm committed to taking care of myself so I can keep up with my kids and be there for Sarah. Health is something I don't take for granted, and I think it's one of those things that you have to work at every single day.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Lance Moran: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine that I can stick to, even on the busiest days. I've found that when I wake up early and take that short run or do a quick yoga session, it sets a positive tone for the rest of the day. It's also helped that Sarah and I have started cooking more meals at home, which means we're eating better and not relying as much on takeout. What makes it hard, though, is the constant juggling act between work, family, and personal time. There are days when I'm so caught up in meetings or helping the kids with homework that I forget to eat properly or get enough rest. I think the biggest challenge is maintaining consistency, especially when life feels like it's moving at a hundred miles an hour. But I've learned that even small choices—like taking the stairs instead of the elevator or choosing a salad over a burger—add up over time. I'm not perfect, but I'm trying to be intentional about my health because I know it's the foundation for everything else in life.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Lance Moran: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some persistent lower back pain, something I think I picked up from years of sitting at a desk and not always taking the time to stretch or move properly. It started as a minor annoyance, something I could ignore most of the time, but it's gotten worse over the past year. I finally saw a physical therapist a few months ago, and it turns out I have some mild disc degeneration. It's not serious, but it's something I need to manage moving forward. The therapist has given me a series of exercises to strengthen my core and improve my posture, and I've been doing them regularly. It's been a bit of a wake-up call, honestly. I've always thought of myself as pretty healthy, but this has made me realize how important it is to take care of my body, not just my mind. I've also started incorporating more movement into my day—like taking short walks during lunch breaks or doing some light stretching at my desk. It's not perfect, but I'm learning that health isn't just about avoiding illness; it's about being proactive and making choices that support your well-being, even when you don't feel like it.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Lance Moran: Honestly, the back pain hasn't really gotten in the way of my work or taking care of the kids, but it has made me more aware of how much I take for granted. I used to think I could push through anything, but this has taught me the value of slowing down and listening to my body. Some days, I have to take it easy, maybe sit down for a bit longer or adjust how I carry things, but I've learned to be more mindful of that. It's also made me more empathetic toward people who deal with chronic pain or health issues—they don't just 'get over it,' and they deserve the same patience and support I'm trying to give myself. I think the biggest thing is that it's reminded me that life isn't just about being productive; it's also about being present, even when you're not at your best. I'm still learning how to balance that, but I'm grateful for the lesson.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Lance Moran: Over the past year, I've felt a lot of things—some good, some challenging. On the positive side, I've really grown closer to my kids. Emily is starting to become more independent, and Jake is just full of curiosity and questions about everything. It's amazing to watch them develop their own personalities. I've also felt more connected to my community here in East Side. I joined a local parenting group, and it's been a great way to meet other families and share experiences. That said, there have been moments of stress and uncertainty. Work has been busy, and with the back pain, I've had to be more intentional about pacing myself. I think the biggest thing is that I've felt more grounded in who I am and what matters most. I've learned to slow down, be present, and not take life for granted. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm on the right path.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily routines and health habits shape the kind of life I live. Talking about my mindfulness practice and the small changes I've made to stay present reminded me of how important it is to take care of myself—not just physically, but mentally and emotionally. Thinking about my health, especially the back pain I've been dealing with, made me realize how much I take for granted. I used to think I could push through anything, but now I understand the value of slowing down and listening to my body. It's also made me more aware of how interconnected everything is—my work, my family, my health, and my well-being. I'm still learning what balance looks like, but I'm committed to keeping the conversation going and making sure I'm present for the people and moments that matter most.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Lance Moran: I think I've been pretty fortunate in that I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way that some people do. That said, there have been moments—especially during the early days of moving to Austin, or when work got overwhelming—that I felt a bit lost or unsure of myself. I remember one particular time, a few years back, when I was juggling a big project at work, helping Sarah with some home renovations, and trying to keep up with the kids' schedules. It felt like I was constantly running on empty, and I wasn't sure how much longer I could keep it up. I didn't really talk about it with anyone, not even Sarah, because I didn't want to burden her. But looking back, I realize that those moments were a sign that I needed to slow down and take a step back. I've since learned the importance of talking through my feelings, even when it's hard. I think the biggest thing is that I've come to accept that it's okay to not be okay sometimes. It's not a weakness—it's just part of being human. And I'm grateful that I've had people in my life who've helped me through those times, even when I didn't ask for it.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Lance Moran: For my family, the past year has been a mix of growth, challenges, and moments of deep connection. Sarah has been doing incredible work as a school counselor, and she's taken on more responsibilities at her job, which has been both rewarding and exhausting for her. I can see how much she cares about her students, and it's inspiring, but I also worry about her stress levels. Emily and Jake have been thriving in their own ways—Emily is becoming more confident, especially in her soccer team, and she's starting to take on more leadership roles at school. Jake, on the other hand, is always full of questions and ideas, and I love seeing his curiosity about the world. We've had our share of tough days, especially when work and life feel overwhelming, but I think we've grown closer as a family. We've started having more meaningful conversations, especially after dinner, where we talk about our day, our feelings, and what's on our minds. It's not perfect, but I think those moments have helped us feel more connected and more grounded. I'm grateful for the support we've given each other, and I know we're all learning how to navigate this chapter of life together.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Lance Moran: When it comes to religion or spirituality, I think my relationship with it has evolved over time. Growing up, I was raised Catholic, and I remember going to church every Sunday with my family. It was a part of our routine, and I even considered becoming a priest for a while. But as I got older, I started to question a lot of the teachings and the role of organized religion in my life. I never really felt a deep connection to the church, and I think that's why I drifted away from it. These days, I don't identify with any particular religion, but I do believe in something bigger than myself. I find spirituality in the everyday moments—like watching my kids grow, being part of this community, or even just taking a walk in the park and feeling the quiet peace of the world around me. I think of it more as a personal journey, something that's not about following rules or doctrines, but about finding meaning and connection in the world. I don't know if I'd call it spirituality or just a sense of gratitude, but I feel like it's what keeps me grounded and reminds me of what's truly important in life.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Lance Moran: To be honest, I'm not really big on social media. I've tried using Facebook in the past, mostly to stay in touch with family back home and some old friends from college, but it never really clicked for me. I find myself scrolling through posts and getting caught up in other people's lives, which doesn't always feel good. Instagram is even worse—there's just so much curated content, and it can be hard not to compare yourself to others. I do use it occasionally to follow some local artists and community events in East Side, which has been a nice way to stay connected to what's happening around me. But overall, I prefer face-to-face interactions or even a good phone call. I think I've learned that the more I focus on being present in my own life, the less I need to look elsewhere for connection. It's not that I'm against it—it's just not something that adds much value to my day.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Lance Moran: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really relied on social media for emotional or financial support. I know a lot of people use it as a way to vent or ask for help, but I've always found that kind of thing harder to do online. There's something about putting your struggles out there for strangers to see that feels too exposed, even if it's well-intentioned. For me, support has always come from the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, my coworkers. When things get tough, I lean on them, not on a screen. That said, I do appreciate the way social media can connect people to resources or communities they might not have access to otherwise. I just don't think it's the same as having someone there in person, listening to you and holding your hand through it. I guess what I'm saying is, I'm grateful for the connections I have, and I think they're enough.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and emotional well-being shape the kind of life I live. Talking about my back pain reminded me of how much I take for granted, and how important it is to listen to my body and take care of myself. Thinking about the moments when I felt lost or overwhelmed made me realize how much I've grown in learning to slow down and be present. It also made me appreciate how much my family has supported me through those times, even when I didn't ask for it. I've come to understand that it's okay to not be okay sometimes, and that asking for help isn't a weakness—it's just part of being human. These reflections have helped me see how deeply connected my physical health, emotional state, and relationships are, and how important it is to nurture all of them.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Lance Moran: In the past year, I've definitely felt my stress levels fluctuate, especially with work demands and the ongoing challenges of balancing family life. There were times when I felt like I was constantly juggling a hundred things at once, and it was hard to keep up. But I've been working on developing better coping strategies. One of the biggest changes has been incorporating mindfulness into my daily routine, like those short meditation sessions I mentioned earlier. It's helped me stay more centered, even on the busiest days. I've also started talking more openly with Sarah about how I'm feeling, which has made a huge difference. It's easy to bottle things up, but I've realized that sharing my worries, even the small ones, helps me process them better. I've also found that spending time in nature—whether it's a walk in the park or just sitting on the porch with a cup of coffee—helps me reset and gain perspective. I'm not saying I've mastered stress, but I feel like I'm learning how to handle it in healthier ways, and that's something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Lance Moran: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and the kids' school-related costs. We're in a two-bedroom apartment in East Side, and the rent is pretty steep for the area, especially with the way housing prices have gone up. Groceries are another big one—between Emily and Jake, they're always trying new foods or asking for snacks, and Sarah and I try to make sure they eat well. Then there's the school stuff: Emily's soccer fees, Jake's piano lessons, and the occasional school supply purchases. We also have car payments and insurance, which adds up. I've been trying to track our budget more closely, and it's been eye-opening. It's not that we're struggling, but it's a constant reminder of how much goes into raising kids and keeping a household running. I've started setting aside a little extra each month for unexpected expenses, just in case. It's not always easy, but I think being mindful of where our money goes helps us stay grounded and make the most of what we have.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Lance Moran: Last month, our household spent roughly around $4,200, which is actually a bit higher than usual. Normally, we hover around $3,800 to $4,000 a month. The increase was mostly due to unexpected car repairs and a few extra expenses for the kids' school activities. Rent is our biggest fixed cost, taking up about $1,800, and groceries usually come in around $800 to $900. The kids' activities, like soccer, piano, and coding classes, add another $400 to $500 each month. We also have health insurance, utilities, and some savings set aside for emergencies. It's not always easy to keep track of everything, but I've started using a budgeting app to help us stay on top of things. It's a learning process, but I think being more intentional about our spending helps us make the most of what we have while still providing for our family.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Lance Moran: We rent our home, actually. It's a two-bedroom apartment in East Side, and while it's not the most spacious place, it's functional and close to everything we need. Renting has been the practical choice for us, especially with the way housing prices have gone up in Austin. We've considered buying, but with the kids and the cost of living, it just doesn't feel like the right move right now. I think we're in a good place for now—renting gives us flexibility, and it's easier to manage with our current financial situation. Plus, it's not like we're stuck here forever; we're always keeping an eye out for opportunities that might come our way in the future.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Lance Moran: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the kids' schedules. In the winter, our utility bills—especially heating—went up, and we had to budget a bit more for that. Then, when school started back up, we had to factor in those extra fees for Emily's soccer season and Jake's coding classes. There was also the holiday season, which brought in a few unexpected costs—gifts for the kids, a family trip to visit my parents, and some holiday meals that ended up being more expensive than we anticipated. On the flip side, during the summer, we didn't have to worry about heating, and some of the kids' activities slowed down, which gave us a bit of a financial breather. I've learned that it's important to plan for these fluctuations, even if it's just setting aside a little extra each month for the unknown. It's not always perfect, but I think it's helped us stay more prepared for the ups and downs of life.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and emotional well-being are intertwined with my sense of purpose and connection. Talking about my family reminded me of how much love, support, and growth we've experienced together, even through the challenges. Thinking about my health and the back pain I've been dealing with made me realize how important it is to take care of my body and mind, not just for myself, but for the people I love. It also made me appreciate how much I rely on my family and close friends for emotional support, rather than turning to social media or online spaces. I've come to understand that my strength comes from the people I know and trust, and that's something I'm incredibly grateful for. These reflections have helped me see how much I value real, meaningful connections over virtual ones, and how much my family is the foundation of my life.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Lance Moran: I do save, though it's more of a habit than a formal plan. I've always believed that even small amounts add up over time, so I try to set aside a portion of my paycheck each month, even if it's just $100 or so. It goes into a high-yield savings account, and I treat it like a non-negotiable part of my budget. I also have an emergency fund that I've been building slowly, mostly by cutting back on unnecessary expenses and being more mindful of where my money goes. It's not a lot, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that we have a little cushion in case something unexpected comes up. I think the biggest thing is that saving isn't just about money for me—it's about discipline, responsibility, and making sure that I'm not just living for today, but also thinking about tomorrow. It's something I've learned from my parents, who always emphasized the importance of planning ahead, even if it meant making sacrifices in the short term. I'm not perfect at it, but I'm trying to be better, and that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Lance Moran: In the last year, I've been saving more with a focus on both short-term and long-term goals. On the short-term side, I've been building up our emergency fund, which has been especially important given the unexpected car repairs and other costs we've had. I also set aside money each month for the kids' activities and school-related expenses, so we're not caught off guard when those bills come in. As for long-term savings, I've been contributing to a retirement account, even if it's a modest amount. It's not something I talk about much, but I think it's important to start early, even if it's just a little at a time. I've also been trying to be more intentional about our overall spending, making sure we're not just surviving but also planning for the future. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm on the right track, and that gives me a sense of security, even if it's small.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Lance Moran: My occupation has been as a policy analyst for a nonprofit organization focused on education reform, and it's been both challenging and rewarding. The most important activities involve researching policies, analyzing data, and working closely with educators, community leaders, and legislators to develop programs that support underprivileged students. A big part of my job is attending meetings, whether it's with school boards, advocacy groups, or government agencies, to discuss how we can improve access to quality education. I also spend a lot of time writing reports and proposals, which can be tedious but necessary for securing funding and support for our initiatives. What I love most about this work is the direct impact it can have on people's lives. I remember one project we worked on a few years back that helped establish a new after-school program in a low-income neighborhood. Seeing the kids thrive in that environment was incredibly fulfilling. It's not always easy—there's a lot of bureaucracy and political pushback—but I believe in what we're doing, and that keeps me motivated. This job has also allowed me to stay connected to the community, which is something I value deeply, especially since I moved to Austin to be part of something bigger than myself.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Lance Moran: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the projects I'm involved in. Some weeks are busier than others, especially when we're finalizing reports or preparing for meetings with legislators or community stakeholders. I try to keep a regular schedule, but there are times when I have to stay late or come in early to meet deadlines. What I've learned over the years is that flexibility is key—being able to adapt to the needs of the job while still making time for my family is something I've had to work on. I've also started setting clearer boundaries, like not checking work emails after 7 p.m. unless it's an emergency. It's not always easy, but I think it's necessary for maintaining a healthy balance. I've seen too many people burn out in this line of work, and I want to make sure I'm not one of them.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Lance Moran: No, I haven't had more than one job in the traditional sense, but I do take on some freelance consulting work on the side, mostly for local schools and community groups. It's not a full-time gig, but it helps me stay connected to the people we're trying to serve and gives me a bit more flexibility with my schedule. I've found that having that extra income, even if it's not a lot, helps take some pressure off the main job and allows me to be more present for my family. It also keeps me grounded in the work I do—reminding me that policy analysis isn't just about reports and meetings, but about real people and real needs. I think it's important to have a variety of experiences, even if they're not all formal jobs. It helps you see the bigger picture and understand how different parts of your life are interconnected.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my daily life is shaped by the balance between stress, emotional well-being, and financial responsibilities. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how important it is to take time for myself, whether it's through mindfulness, conversation with Sarah, or simply being in nature. Thinking about my monthly budget and the fluctuating expenses brought home how much goes into keeping our household running, and how much I've learned to be intentional with our spending. It also made me appreciate how much my family and I have grown in learning to manage life's challenges together. I've come to understand that financial stability, emotional health, and family support are all deeply connected, and that finding balance in all of them is what keeps me grounded and moving forward.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Lance Moran: In total, our household made around $6,500 in the past month. That comes from my full-time job as a policy analyst and the freelance consulting work I do on the side. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our expenses and save a little for the future. I've been trying to be more transparent about our finances with Sarah and the kids, especially as they get older and start to understand the value of money. It's not always easy talking about money, but I think it's important for them to see how we manage it and what choices we make. I've also been working on improving my financial literacy, reading up on budgeting strategies and investing basics. It's something I wish I had learned earlier, but I'm grateful I'm starting now. I think the biggest lesson I've learned is that money isn't just about earning—it's about managing, planning, and being mindful of what you spend and why.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Lance Moran: I've been at my current job for almost a decade now, and it's been a journey. The benefits package is pretty standard for a nonprofit—health insurance, dental, vision, and a decent amount of paid time off. We get about three weeks of vacation each year, plus sick days and holidays. I think what makes the benefits meaningful is how they align with the mission of the organization. For example, the health insurance covers mental health services, which I've found really valuable, especially during the more stressful times in my life. The flexibility of the job also allows me to take time off when I need it, whether it's for family or personal reasons. I've taken a few weeks off to be with Sarah during her more demanding work periods, and the team has always been supportive. I think the biggest benefit isn't just the tangible things like insurance or vacation days—it's the sense of purpose that comes with knowing my work is making a real difference in people's lives. That's something you can't put a price on.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Lance Moran: My relationships at work are pretty much what you'd expect from a nonprofit environment—collaborative, supportive, and driven by a shared mission. I've been lucky to have a manager, Clara, who's both competent and compassionate. She's the kind of leader who trusts her team and gives them the space to do their best work. I've had my disagreements with her, of course, but she's always been open to feedback and willing to listen. As for my coworkers, I'd say we're all in this together. We're not just colleagues; we're a team of people who genuinely care about the work we do. I've built strong relationships with a few of them over the years—people like Marcus, who I mentioned earlier, and a few others who've become like family. We support each other through the ups and downs, and that sense of camaraderie makes the job more than just a paycheck. It's one of the reasons I've stayed in this role for so long—it's not just about the work, but the people I get to do it with.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Lance Moran: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a fair amount of flexibility, which I really appreciate. Most days, I start around 8 a.m. and finish by 5 p.m., though I often stay a little later on busy days or leave a bit early if I need to pick up the kids from school. The flexibility is one of the things that makes this job work for me—it allows me to adjust my hours when needed, whether it's for a family event or to take care of something personal. That said, there are times when the schedule can be less predictable, especially when we're preparing for big meetings or working on tight deadlines. I've learned to be proactive about planning my time, and I've also gotten pretty good at communicating with my manager when I need to adjust my hours. It's not perfect, but I think the balance between structure and flexibility is what makes this job sustainable for me, both professionally and personally.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Lance Moran: Overall, I feel pretty good about our financial situation, though it's not without its challenges. We're not wealthy by any means, but we're stable enough to cover our needs and save a little for the future. I think the biggest thing is that we've learned to be intentional with our money, which has helped us avoid unnecessary debt and stay on top of our expenses. I know there are people who have it much harder than we do, and that keeps me grounded. I also feel lucky that my job provides a steady income, and the freelance work adds a little extra security. It's not always easy balancing everything, but I think we're doing okay. What matters most to me is that we're not sacrificing our values or our family time for financial stability. I've seen too many people burn out trying to chase more, and I want to make sure we're living a life that's meaningful, not just one that's measured by how much we earn.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation and daily responsibilities shape the kind of life I live. Talking about our fluctuating bills reminded me of how much goes into keeping our household running, and how important it is to plan for the unexpected. Thinking about our monthly budget and the effort it takes to manage our expenses brought home how much I've learned to be intentional with our spending. It also made me appreciate how much my job and freelance work contribute to our stability, even if it's not always easy balancing everything. I've come to understand that financial responsibility is not just about numbers—it's about making choices that support my family and the life we've built together. These reflections have helped me see how deeply connected my work, my family, and my financial habits are, and how important it is to stay grounded in all of them.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Lance Moran: Yes, both my mom and dad worked while I was growing up, though their roles were different. My father worked full-time as an engineer for over thirty years, and he was always very dedicated to his job. He had a strong work ethic, and I remember seeing him come home tired but always making time for our family. My mother, on the other hand, worked part-time as a nurse, which gave her more flexibility to be around for school events and family dinners. She was the one who really kept our household running, and I think that's where I got my sense of responsibility. Both of them worked hard to provide for us, and I always felt grateful for the stability they gave me. It's interesting to think about how their work shaped my own views on responsibility and the value of a good job. I think that's one of the reasons I ended up in the field I'm in now—because I saw how their work made a difference, not just for our family, but for others too.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Lance Moran: My father worked as an engineer for a construction company, and his most important activities involved designing and overseeing infrastructure projects—everything from roads and bridges to water systems. He was the kind of person who could look at a blueprint and visualize the whole structure in his mind before it was even built. He had a real passion for his work, and I remember him talking about how satisfying it was to see a project come to life. My mother worked part-time as a nurse at a local clinic, and her most important duties involved caring for patients, administering treatments, and providing emotional support. She was especially good with children, and I think that's why she found her work so rewarding. Both of them had their own ways of making a difference, and I think that's what inspired me to choose a career that also focuses on helping others, even if it's through policy and education rather than hands-on care.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Lance Moran: My father worked for a mid-sized construction company based in our town, and they specialized in infrastructure projects like building roads, bridges, and water systems. It was a family-owned business, and I remember visiting the office sometimes when I was a kid. They had blueprints spread out all over the place, and my dad would explain what each part meant. He was the lead engineer on most of their projects, which meant he was out on site a lot, supervising workers and making sure everything was up to code. My mom worked at a local clinic that served a lot of low-income families, and she was part of a small team of nurses and doctors. She didn't make a lot of money, but she always said that the work was its own reward. I think that's why I ended up in the field I'm in now—because I saw how their work made a difference, not just for our family, but for others too. It's funny, though, because while my dad was always focused on the big picture, my mom was the one who made sure the day-to-day stuff got done. I think that's where I got my sense of responsibility and the belief that even small actions can have a big impact.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Lance Moran: If I imagine myself a few years from now, I hope I'm still living in East Side, still working on issues that matter, and still being there for my family. I hope Emily and Jake are growing into the kind of people they want to be—confident, curious, and kind. I hope they have the same sense of purpose that I've been trying to cultivate in myself. I also hope that I've continued to grow as a person, not just professionally but emotionally and spiritually. I want to be someone who's not just surviving but truly living, someone who's present for the moments that matter and who's still learning, still exploring, and still connected to the people and places that have shaped me. I don't know exactly what that will look like, but I hope it's a life that feels full, meaningful, and grounded in the values I hold dear—family, community, and the belief that we can all make a difference, even in small ways.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Lance Moran: What I value the most in my life is connection—connection with my family, with my community, and with the world around me. I think it's easy to get caught up in the hustle of work and responsibilities, but what keeps me grounded is the people I love and the relationships I nurture. Sarah, Emily, and Jake are the heart of my life, and I value every moment we have together. I also value the sense of purpose that comes from working on issues that matter, like education reform. It's not always easy, but knowing that my work can make a difference, even in small ways, gives me a sense of fulfillment. I value the friendships I've built over the years, the mentors who believed in me, and the community in East Side that feels like home. And I value the little things—the quiet mornings with my kids, the laughter over dinner, the walks in the park, the conversations that matter. Life is made up of these moments, and I want to make sure I'm present for them all.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my work and financial responsibilities shape the kind of life I live. Talking about my household income and expenses reminded me of how much goes into keeping our family afloat, and how important it is to be intentional with our money. Thinking about my job as a policy analyst and the benefits that come with it brought home how lucky I am to have a role that not only pays the bills but also aligns with my values. It also made me appreciate the relationships I've built at work—the supportive team, the understanding manager, and the sense of purpose that comes from knowing my work matters. I've come to understand that financial stability and meaningful work are deeply connected, and that finding balance in both is what keeps me grounded and moving forward.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and connection. It's amazing how telling my story from the beginning brought back so many memories and made me realize how deeply my identity is tied to the people and places I've chosen. From my childhood in Texas to moving to Austin and making the conscious decision to pursue a path that aligned with my values, every step has shaped who I am today. Thinking about my family—Sarah, Emily, and Jake—reminds me of how much love and effort it takes to build a life, and how lucky I am to have them in my corner. My parents, my mentors, and the community in East Side have all played a role in shaping my journey, and I'm grateful for their support. Reflecting on my work as a policy analyst, my health struggles, my financial responsibilities, and the balance I strive to maintain between work, family, and personal well-being has given me a clearer picture of what matters most. This interview has helped me see how interconnected everything is—my past, my present, and my future—and how important it is to stay grounded in the values that guide me. I'm still learning, still growing, but I feel more connected to who I am and what I want for my life than ever before.
